comments.content:
Best to go conservative.

The Truth shall set you free
No way: a professor I once had described Cooper Black as "honest" type. I can't see that this particular characteristic has anything to do with elections...

i'd think you'd want something oblique... something with a slant to it.

\>^p

You know, this reminds me of an article from way back, and [the analysis](http://web.archive.org/web/20110821044108/http:/www.nytimes.com/imagepages/2004/10/08/opinion/20041009_opart2.html) (by none other than Paula Scher) that accompanied it.

[The article](http://web.archive.org/web/20110821044108/http:/www.nytimes.com/2004/10/09/opinion/09dadich.html?ex=1158465600&en=c209978a12e3a466&ei=5070).

What use are you putting it to?

It is well-rounded, attractive and charismatic, so not really representative of politicians, on the other hand it does work hard for headlines:)

Tim
I think it's too retro looking right now.

I think Cooper Black works well for the Dem's - they have a donkey for an icon for cry'n'out loud! They're not exactly looking for a slick image. The GOP however is much more controlling of their public glossy visual identity - they're the Apple of the political world.
Maybe in 1881. "Garfield tips the scales!" "Garfield takes the cake!"
The typeface doesn't matter. All that matters is that you use Red, White, Blue and a handful of stars sprinkled around it.
Its fine whats important is the content of the article. No one cares about the look of that headline.
